title: Upright italic
content:
Does anyone know of an upright italic, without any slant, that also has a normal roman form?   
No reason, just curious.
author: �rian

comments.content:
Well, Unibody from Underware is a bitmap family that comes with an upright italic and roman. The best part is that it's free.   
   
 [http://www.underware.nl/site2/index.php3?id1=unibody&id2=overview](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123852/http:/www.underware.nl/site2/index.php3?id1=unibody&id2=overview)   
   
A quick google search also found this gem:   
   
 [http://www.micropress-inc.com/fonts/ecfonts/ecf1s.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123852/http:/www.micropress-inc.com/fonts/ecfonts/ecf1s.htm)

_A quick google search also found this gem:   
   
 [http://www.micropress-inc.com/fonts/ecfonts/ecf1s.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123852/http:/www.micropress-inc.com/fonts/ecfonts/ecf1s.htm)_   
      
   
It never ceases to amaze me how uninspired the typography of TEX tends to be. There must be some sort of inverse relationship between design aptitude and ability to grasp TEX.   
   
I thought the extra-inclusive pangram near the bottom of the page was pretty cool, though.

Indeed. But maybe the following explains why the TeX type is generally function over form:   
   
_quite a few TeX installations are routinely using commercial Type 1 fonts, especially if they're not producing heavily technical material; only Computer Modern (the font Knuth developed), Lucida Bright, and Times have anywhere near a comprehensive symbol complement, and none of the symbol sets are from "major" font suppliers (too much work, not enough money; the demise of Monotype's symbol catalog � metal only � is a particularly great loss)._   
   
From [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20050518123852/http:/www.tug.org/whatis.html) page

\> The best part is that [Unibody is] free.   
   
While the worst part is that the only way to effectively mark emphasis with Unibody is to use the Regular in a body of Bold...   
   
Brian, the most prominent font with an upright italic (although it's actually slanted by [an average of] 1/2 a degree) is FF Seria. Of course that one doesn't work either.
